results.headline: The High Human Cost of Following the Money in the Madoff Fraud Case

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Chasing Madoff!

results.summary_short: “It took five minutes” to spot fraud in Bernard L. Madoff’s funds, Harry Markopolos said. But according to “Chasing Madoff,” it took years to get the federal government to listen.

results.headline: Documentary on Shipbreakers, and Where Tankers Go When They Die

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Iron Crows

results.summary_short: Destruction meets beauty, and optimism meets poverty, in the images and words of the film “Iron Crows.”

results.headline: Cantonese Erotic Fantasy: 3-D and One Lousy Lover

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Sex and Zen 3D: Extreme Ecstasy

results.summary_short: In “3D Sex and Zen: Extreme Ecstasy,” said to be based on an ancient Chinese tale, the sex looks rather nonecstatic.

results.headline: Very Busy Mom Faces a Bigger Mission
results.display_title: Spy Kids: All The Time in The World

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Spy Kids: All The Time in The World

results.summary_short: The fourth “Spy Kids” installment, written and directed, as always, by Robert Rodriguez, introduces a new family.

results.headline: 2 Clowns and the Surreal Pursuit of Love

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Last Circus

results.summary_short: Álex de la Iglesia’s “Last Circus” views Franco-era Spain through a love triangle involving one magnificent woman.

results.headline: When Murder Is Just Another Film Pitch

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Scenesters

results.summary_short: When someone starts killing trendy young adults in Los Angeles, two filmmakers pursue their breakout project by following a crime-scene cleanup specialist in “The Scenesters.”

results.headline: Behind the Prickliness Lies a Generous Heart

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Hedgehog

results.summary_short: Muriel Barbery’s novel “The Elegance of the Hedgehog” was the inspiration for the “The Hedgehog,” in which a bright but fatalistic child learns the joy of life from some eccentric elders.

results.headline: Powers of Hidden Persuasion

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Programming the Nation?

results.summary_short: Jeff Warrick’s “Programming the Nation?” takes a jaundiced look at so-called subliminal techniques in advertising and mass media.

results.headline: Emma and Dex and July 15

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of One Day

results.summary_short: “One Day,” directed by Lone Scherfig, follows a man and a woman for more than 20 years, with the action taking place on a single date, July 15, every year.

results.headline: The Other Child in Papa Mozart’s Musical Troupe

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Mozart's Sister

results.summary_short: “Mozart’s Sister” is an intimate portrait of a family bound by love, genius and ambition and almost undone by the same.

results.headline: The Cause Is Familiar, but the War Is Less So

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Amigo

results.summary_short: “Amigo,” a new film by John Sayles, is set in the Philippines around 1900, when American forces arrived as liberators and quickly became an army of occupation.

results.headline: A Meek Superhero Bravely Awaits S.O.S.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Griff the Invisible

results.summary_short: The superhero-hopeful in “Griff the Invisible” is an office drone with no friends, a mouse who tries to roar but usually squeaks.

results.headline: Those Good, Old Vampires, and Now They’re in 3-D

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Fright Night

results.summary_short: “Fright Night,” directed by Craig Gillespie and a remake of the 1985 vampire film with the same name, takes its time getting to its fiery finish.

results.headline: ‘Hey, We’re Robbing This Bank!’ ‘No, We Are!’

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Flypaper

results.summary_short: In the comedy caper “Flypaper” two gangs try to steal from a bank at the same time. Complications and shootouts ensue.

results.headline: Keep Hold of Your Head, Lest He Lop It Off With the Others

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Conan the Barbarian

results.summary_short: “Conan the Barbarian,” starring Jason Momoa as the title character, delights in gore and swords.

results.headline: Boxing in the Blood and Bones

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Born and Bred

results.summary_short: Justin Frimmer’s “Born and Bred” offers a vérité portrait of three young Mexican-American boxers in East Los Angeles.

results.headline: The Serial-Killer Story Takes a New Twist

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of A Horrible Way to Die

results.summary_short: Adam Wingard’s “Horrible Way to Die” turns a typical idea into an unexpectedly novel thriller.

results.headline: More Than One Kind of Deadline

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of 5 Days of War

results.summary_short: “5 Days of War” is a fictionalized account of the 2008 fighting between Russia and Georgia.

results.headline: Dear Leader, I’ve Made a Friend in the South

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Journals of Musan

results.summary_short: Park Jungbum directs and stars in “The Journals of Musan,” about a North Korean defector’s problems dealing with the cold realities of capitalism.

results.headline: A Life Herding Yaks, Modernity on the Horizon

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Summer Pasture

results.summary_short: Lynn True, Nelson Walker and Tsering Perlo followed a young family living as Tibetans have for 4,000 years, but aware of the pressures of modern life.
